comments.commentBody:
I was tempted to use an anagram website, but then I realized that such "cheating" would not make any sense. There is an old expression about "cheating at solitaire", and I guess that cheating at a puzzle is in the same category.

Anyway, #4 is PROSE POSER.
#14 is PROTEIN POINTER.
#15 is PARROTED PREDATOR.
#20 (and also #12) I have been unable to get.

Oh, and like I said, I had given up on #12 as well as #20.

Meg, maybe you're right about the word that also means somebody who's walking.
Can you or anybody else help with #12?
got every answer to both puzzles, except #2 wrath--- wracking my brain!! what am i missing??

JolleyGood,

The answer is listed in
http://www.merriam-webster.com/

with a definition very close to the clue.

I really enjoyed the rotating connections between the theme answers, very clever construction.

I had no idea what a Supermax is, I was thinking some kind of movie theater. I guess that would apply if it were a captive audience. The idea of a spinning record player (rather than just the platter) is intriguing. Never heard of CLEON.

Jim, does the name Clapper ring a bell?
@JolleyGood:  It's not really obscure, but it might be seen as a bit retro.  Hope I haven't jumped the GUN here.

Jolley: Took me a few minutes, but a vivacious person is a PISTOL. Bit of trick cluing there.

This was a nice variation on a word ladder. It went quickly except for the north west, where I was stuck on variations of CREAM or CREMA as a latte topper, until I got FROTH. Still, a half hour for a Sunday puzzle is nice, and it never felt like too much work (as some Sundays do. Rarely, of course.)

Jim, at times your humor makes me salivate.

No, we don't, at least not directly.  What we do is to tolerate too many incompetent drivers who indulge in unsafe practices, such as cell phone use, then buy SUVs seeking an illusory (because SUVs aren't really safer) safety from the actions of drivers like themselves.

It all is a bit much and embarassing for a child to know such manner of their birth. I would counsel the mother to delay relating the story when the child is old enough to understand such matters and be psychologically strong and mature enough to appreciate the circumstances. And perhaps to fib if necessary.
Yes, tell him it was a BMW.

Drinking

Sadly this not well advertised but 1 of 3 fatalities is from drinking:

Drinking and driving fatalities by state in 2008
http://www.alcoholalert.com...

National: 37%

Texas 43% (1,463 of 3,382)
California 35% (1,198 of 3,434)

North Dakota 50%
South Carolina 50%

Do We Tolerate Too Many Traffic Deaths? Yes, 30% are from stupidity

Within a surprisingly few years, we could actually have a chance to replace the most dangerous part of a motor vehicle: the nut behind the wheel.  The potential for robotics in this area is very real and could eliminate almost all collisions while saving untold billions at the cost of many of the best jobs for those with limited formal educations.

I lived on Homestead AFB, FL one summer and we had the same problem there. As Ed in Boston said, the roads got slippery from all the squashed frogs. (To Matt in Saint Augustine: They were so dense, they were impossible to miss.) And then when it got hot and dry for a few days, all the flattened frogs turned into thin sheets of dried frog leather. Dried frog leather would blow around in the wind, just as autumn leaves fly around in the wind in the northern states.

My experience was about 30 years ago and don't know if they still have that problem there or not. But I have had no desire to move back to Homestead.

Well, they're sovereign nations who will do what they will, and actually seem more open to a green future than one might expect. Cap'n: what were you doing for a living in 1775? It must be great to remember that far back.

I have bought a new Mazda 2, 1.5 litre manual here in New Zealand. Its a brilliant little car. Most of my driving is highway and the worst fuel consumption I have had is 32 mpg and the best 38 mpg. The fuel consumption figures quoted for the US spec versions seem very conservative as I dont really drive for maximum economy because this car is so much fun to drive and I easily get better mileage.

I think Q has a point. The photo here still shows freeways. What about a mock up of LA with the pedestrian density and sidewalk network of say SF or Vancouver (sorry, my bias is showing here). Cars mess up everything!

Here is what cities look like without cars. But with people.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ELa5CHsUepo

Destroy the asphalt in the roads, plant them with grass and flowers, put in water canals with boats, like Venice. Build tramways and bicycle routes. LA would be the flowering nucleus of a new world awakening. Take the planet back from the industrial revolution run amuck. That's where the war against tobacco started. Now lets get those noisy engines and crowding metal.

Masataka Nakano spend over a decade capturing images of a more populous, much more frenetic city without cars or people in his book "Tokyo Nobody" published in 2000.

Nakano's haunting images were not the product of digital manipulation and other such technological shortcuts, but patience and determination.

Both Ching and Logue images are indeed imaginary, whereas Nakano presents us with the real thing.

Tell us if there is a correlation to crash rates, injury rates, fatalities, insurance rates, etc. That would actually be useful information; this survey is just headline material, which will cause some hand wringing, but probably won't move the safety establishment any closer to doing something about the human factor. Expect more passive and active safety features to be added to vehicles, but little or no discussion about actually making people accountable for what they do behind the wheel.

I am 35. I have moved 4 times since I became a driver. I have had my driving skills and knowledge tested only once. I have had my vision checked in each state, but no road test or written test was required.

Why is this country so obsessed with deaths? How about the number of people injured in traffic accidents per year, or is that an all too unsettling number?

Driving, is the only activity that most working adults participate in with absolutely no reward for improvement. It matters not if I drive observing the speed limit, run a red light without a camera, pull out in front of someone, or be courteous and let somebody out. It only matters if I get caught doing something wrong.

Perhaps that's why the roads are filled with incompetent road users.

u guys should invent flying cars n then turn the roads into ongoing parks. that is my opinion only. plz dont consider it controversial. no offense.

from los angeles itself
Oh...and this game would have sold out in Seattle.

I just wanted to congratulate every person on this thing that has been barking in favor of Torres for the last year. This team is much better with a real central midfielder (not unproductive "ball-winners")...and it's Edu that should partner with him, not Bradley (happen any minute now).

Say what you will about the slippery back four, but they shut out a fine offense...not England...but better than Algeria or Slovenia.

Well, there's really no reason to get a T. Sure, emotions run high and yes, you have to play this game with passion and energy ... but football is an even more violent and confrontational game, and there are plenty of football players who make it through a season or two (16-32 games), or more, without an unsportsmanlike conduct penalty, or even an egregious after-the-whistle type physical penalty.

Also, though I don't know the comparative statistics, it seems to me that in basketball, T's are rarer at the college and high school levels than in the NBA. And since hoops is a game where only the truly elite players make it to the pros, could it be that once they get there, they simply are less apt to view the refs as authority figures? Maybe Kendrick & some others simply need to remember what most of us learn from being stopped for traffic tickets or whatever: you just don't argue with a cop or misbehave in front of one.
I like bagels too!
